--- Comment #1 from Lluís (<mailto:lluis.revilla@gmail.com|lluis.revilla@gmail.com>) ---
I agree that checking and fixing this on R side would be a nice idea. 

RFC5646 is quite complex and seems to cover subtags:
<https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5646#section-4.1> and some other complex tags.
The most obvious errors could be detected automatically. 

However, even if the field is not required it can be used by other tools: for
instance pkgdown could use of that field to set the language of the websites it
generates (<https://github.com/r-lib/pkgdown/pull/2808>) or spelling check use it
(see spelling package). So it would be wrong to just force an error if it is
`en` or similar subtags.

*[Bug 16721] image() with png() plot error for certain pixel widths*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16721>

--- Comment #14 from Paul Murrell (<mailto:paul@stat.auckland.ac.nz|paul@stat.auckland.ac.nz>) ---
Thanks for all of the testing work (and the latest patch).

Unfortunately, that is quite a large number of differences (particularly for
{lattice} and {ggplot}).  I would expect to see some differences when there are
rectangles being drawn because the patch may introduce 1-pixel changes in
rectangle width or height.  However, the example differences that you attached,
e.g., a difference in an arrow head, appear to have nothing to do with
rectangles.

Were there any differences that involve drawing rectangles?  e.g., perhaps the
lattice::barchart() ones?

The fact that the differences are not particularly visible to the naked eye
does not save us.  That is one of the specific advantages of automated visual
diff'ing like what {gdiff} provides.  Not only are we saved from the tedium of
visual inspection, but we will pick up changes that our eyes might not spot. 
If there is a difference between two PNGs that are both produced by Cairo,
particularly on the same platform, and particularly not involving any text
(fonts), there really should be a reason for that difference in the code.

Unfortunately, I cannot immediately think of what the source of those
differences might be.  It may require debugging the example that produces the
different images, on both unpatched and patched R, tracking it down to calls on
the Cairo device, and seeing if anything, including anything in the 'gc'
structure, is different.

Another thing to check for {lattice} and {ggplot2} is that you have exactly the
same package version (and in the case of {ggplot2} then same package versions
for all dependencies) on both patched and unpatched R.

*[Bug 18818] WRE rules about Language entry in DESCRIPTION are not enforced*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18818>

--- Comment #2 from Michael Chirico (<mailto:michaelchirico4@gmail.com|michaelchirico4@gmail.com>) ---
While giving a technically precise in/out decision on `Language` may be
prohibitive, the Syntax and Appendix A examples there suggest we can get good
mileage out of

```
grepl("[a-z][a-z0-9-]*[a-z0-9]", Language, ignore.case=TRUE)
```

<https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5646#section-2.1>
<https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5646#appendix-A>

That would hit ~30 packages on CRAN, mostly about using `_` instead of `-`:

<https://github.com/search?q=org%3Acran+path%3ADESCRIPTION+%2F%5ELanguage%3A%5Cs%2B%28%5B%5Ea-z%5D%7C%5Ba-z%5D%5Ba-z0-9-%5D*%5B%5Ea-z0-9%5Cn-%5D%7C%5Ba-z%5D%5Ba-z0-9-%5D*%5B%5Ea-z0-9%5D%24%29%2F&type=code>

Note that my example of `NL` would actually be allowed:

> [T]he tag "mn-Cyrl-MN" is not distinct from "MN-cYRL-mn" or "mN-cYrL-Mn" (or any other combination), and each of these variations conveys the same meaning: Mongolian written in the Cyrillic script as used in Mongolia.

(I would propose this being a `NOTE`, something to be addressed on next
submission, rather than something worthy of CRAN removal)

Good point about {pkgdown}, though I think `Language: en` is still fair to
require as a default, in line with what's in WRE unless that should be changed.
I think your point is more relevant for allowing `en-US`.
